plist.p: Welcome to Schneider Electric 2012 Half-Year Results Presentation. I now hand over to Mr. Jean-Pascal Tricoire, Chief Executive Officer. Sir, please go ahead.

Well, good day. Good morning to all the people following this half-year review of the results of Schneider Electric. I'm here with Carina Ho and Emmanuel Babeau, and we're going to go through a quick presentation of our results and then we're going to be happy to take the possible questions about this first mid-year 2012. So going straight into the program of this presentation, I'm going to go through a very quick overview of Schneider, then come back on our strategy and business update. And then Emmanuel will go into the financial presentation, and then I'm going to go back to the outlook for the year.

So a very quick overview about Schneider; €23 billion of sales over the last 12 months; 40% of our sales in new economies; close to 40% of our sales in Solutions; and we are at a very interesting point in time where the business of the group is completely balanced between the Americas which represent roughly 30% of our sales, Western Europe roughly 30% of our sales, Asia Pac around 30% of our sales, so a very, very balanced presence on business around the world. Remind you that we have a very strong commitment and sustainable development will be by our mission, which is to help our customers to make the most of their energy and particularly to reduce energy consumption and also complete commitment to corporate social responsibility, a multi-faceted commitment that we measure every quarter in terms of progress on results.

Now, I'm going to go through the review of this first half and first go to the headlines of the main achievements of the first half. And as we said at the beginning of the year, we've been totally focused on execution – operational execution. In the first half, the main achievements have been, first, pricing power; price increases by €141 million in H1 and I'm going to come back to that. But with that, we have covered 80% of the raw material impact that affected us last year. Then operational efficiency, our adjusted operating result, adjusted EBITA increased by 9%; the earnings per share plus 10%. Our cash generation is back to a normal profile after a disturbed 2011 year. And the free cash flow over the last 12 months is equivalent to 108% of our net income.

Then this first half has been also characterized by a strong activity of integration of the acquisitions we realized last year and the year before. A lot of things happening in the domain of smart infrastructure with the integration of Telvent, a lot of acquisition in the field of services, and the rest of acquisitions were so devoted to the development of our presence into new economies. And finally, we kept working on the improvement of our business model in Solutions and services, and particularly we started generating higher margins on the efficiency of our operational assets in the cities. So, with that we – and I'll come back to that. We are confirming the full-year outlook that we gave at the beginning of the year.

Now, let's have a review in more details business by business. Our Power business has very strong dynamics. As it's well known, it represents 38% of our business, plus 3% on the full first half of organic growth and plus 8.7% of current growth. Well, we have – this business is very resilient in – and is very diversified in terms of market exposure, geographical exposure. And we fully benefit of our strong leadership worldwide. Infrastructure, flattish over the first half, minus 0.7%, the current growth of 17%. Well, we had said very clearly that the priority in this business was to realize – finalize the integration of Schneider, Areva and Telvent. So a lot of work devoted to this integration, to making sure that the organizations are well merged together, that the synergies are put into place, on clear priority in measuring our margin and our profit and Solutions model. This has been well done. We are developing very satisfactory oil services. We are developing our Solutions for infrastructure, for oil and gas. This semester has been also characterized by the lower demand from utilities.

Industry business, minus 6.3% in terms of organic growth, minus 0.4% in terms of current growth. Well, we've been impacted by a tough market in Western Europe and also tough market in Asia, impacted also by our lower exposure to North America in this sector. We are now launching equal structure for manufacturing for plant, which we call plant structure. And this is doing a good success so we expect growth on that side on the future. Outstanding performance of our IT business plus 5% of organic growth, plus 23% of current growth. Good performance across all board especially in services, and we are benefiting on the revamping, retrofit adaptation of data centers to the new trend around co-location, virtualization on cloud computing on our very energy-efficient solution are very popular with high-tech actors in these sectors.

And finally, Buildings which is negative in this first half by 2%, plus 9% in terms of current growth. We're clearly impacted by the reduced public spending in Western Europe, and we had weakness in advanced services, particularly performance contracting, due mainly to a basis of comparison which was quite high last year. This activity is suffering of lower exposures, as we have said many times, to new economies, exposure that we are developing but it takes time and we are not yet there.

Going to next slide and going to one of the major characteristics of our growth profile, we are a very balanced company. We are present in all geographies. Well, firstly in this first half there's a sharp or striking contrast between Western Europe and North America; North America plus 4% of organic growth; Western Europe minus 4%, with clearly different dynamics between Southern Europe which is negative and Northern Europe which remains dynamic. So, that's the first thing to underline.

The second point that Asia Pac is slightly negative, minus 1%, due to negative sales in China. But China has stabilized, roughly at the level of Q1. India is doing good but this is – this has variations according to business. Actually, the newly acquired Luminous is having very strong dynamics. And it's likely that power outages, as the one happening at the moment in India, will catalyze more sells on this side. Very, very good results in Southeast Asia, which is extremely dynamic for us. So, China which is in fact suffering from a very high basis of comparison last year and which has stabilized at a very decent level is being compensated by good dynamics in Southeast Asia.

And finally, Latin America, Africa, Middle East and Eastern Europe is the strongest growth of this first half, plus 6%. And we have particularly good growth in Africa, Middle East and Russia particularly. Once again, new economies are the growth engine of Schneider. As you know, they are a strong engine of our strategy, a strong focus of our strategy. And they deliver an organic growth which is 5% above the one of mature countries.

Going to the next worksite of Schneider, this is our Solutions business model which, on the last 12 months, represents 39% of our business. As you know, we've been working a lot on the improvement of the margin and of the asset efficiency devoted to this activity, and we will contract this into the Solutions model with enough simplification, with the specialization of our project on the equipment footprint across the world, with making sure that we develop more reference designs across eco structure and making sure also that we grow the capability of our Solutions centers.

We are working also on the improvement of the financial performance, the cost effectiveness of our equipments. We inherited, with the acquisition of Areva, a diversity of equipment with Schneider. We are rationalizing all of this. We have been more selective on our project pipeline, and I'll come back to the effect of that. And we are working on the development and the acceleration of our services, which is showing good results. So, a consequence of that is the first signs of profitability improvement on our Solutions business model, but at the same time, also due to basis of comparison, higher comps, the growth rate on our Solutions business is decreasing but it's a strict application of our operational orientation to make sure that we master well this model before accelerating it in a more – in a stronger way. Anyway, second growth engine of the company, Solutions, in the first half delivered an organic growth which is 6% above the one of the Products; so new economies plus 5%, Solutions plus 6%.

Going now on the operational efficiency, the first half was also characterized by a continued improvement or effort on pricing to compensate the raw material impact and also values of branding, the innovation and the commercial effort put on the sale, we brought on-board €141 million of prices. I remind you that we measure pricing only on the Products part of the business. And at the end of this first half, after 18 months of continued price increases, we have covered 80% of the raw material inflation – of the inflation, sorry, that we have known particularly in 2011. We intend to keep going with price increases in H2 but it won't be at the same level of H1. Will it be – simply due to the effects of higher basis of comparison last year.

Now going into cost initiatives, we worked on our manufacturing productivity obviously, but clearly, there was a very significant difference of volume increase in H1 this year. Actually, our volumes were in decrease of 1.2%. We nevertheless kept generating productivity at the level of €120 million. And we kept working also on our base cost efficiency and gained 40 basis points of efficiency on our support function cost. I want to mention that we did this productivity on base costs while increasing our R&D spending, which on the first half is representing 4.6% of our sales. And speaking in cash terms, a part of this is capitalized. So we drove SG&A reduction, but in this mix we kept increasing, as we said at the beginning of Connect, our R&D expenses.

Going into next slide, slide 14, and speaking about the cash, I would say this is back to the normal profile of cash generation at Schneider. We've generated roughly €400 million of cash in H1 2012. And if we look back to the past 12 months, we've generated more than €2 billion of cash, which is I think historical for us and generated a cash conversion of 108% of the net income. Remind also our commitment to shareholders, we have decided a payment of a dividend per share of €1.7. We have a long-term dividend policy of 50% payout, which we had been implementing for the past eight years. And the yield at the current share price is 3.6%, which is in the economy of today and the environment today a very attractive return.

We shall continue to focus on cash. We've done a good job in all aspects of cash generation. We also know and you also know that the profile of cash generation at Schneider is very unbalanced between H1 and H2. And the highest spot of the cash generation will obviously happen in H2, and we have all reasons to believe that this year will be a very positive year in terms of cash generation.

Moving on to slide 15, and I wanted to put some emphasis on some other growth and development engines that appeared very clearly in H1. Beyond new economies, beyond Solutions, Schneider is generating growth, thanks to innovation. So as I said, 4.6% of our sales in R&D, that represents 11,000-plus engineers throughout the world close to the most advanced customers, close to the best universities. I should put here the 15,000-plus application on (15:44) engineers who do integration close to the customers of Solutions. They participate to our innovation capabilities. But here you have a few examples of the innovation that came online this year.

Premset which is a very innovative, medium-voltage breaker that was born from the engineers (16:04) on Schneider Electric, very compact, very small size in an environment that needs compacity because it has to be installed in building or small technical rooms in the Industry on a product which for the first time has been designed for integration by partners, panel builders, all over the world, therefore deployment which is very optimized for new economies.

Acti9, which is a full replacement of our miniature circuit breaker line of Products where we are absolute world leaders, but actually the replacement of Acti9 is having in the first year negative impact on our P&L because of the time we ramp up this new line of products which is very – which is a big production volume. We have not yet reached the target cost of design of product, and we are substituting a line of products which was more than five years old and which was very, very efficient in terms of cost. So good thing is that substitution is working very well, but it is impacting slightly negatively our cost line. And finally StruxureWare, our software integration platform for the main applications that we are now deploying in all our key segments, and particularly the major launch of this – at the end of this first half is regarding Buildings and is regarding manufacturing.

Going to my last slide, I'm going to last year of growth beyond new economies, Solutions and innovation are the acquisitions. Here, you'll find a few names of companies that we'd acquired last year or the beginning of this year, which reinforce our presence in services and particularly energy services, smart infrastructure, efficient infrastructure with the core addition of Telvent to Schneider Electric. And finally, our development in new economies with companies like Steck or Luminous will bring both offers adapted to those countries and at the same time a very popular retail network. So, a very dense H1.
And now to go more into the details, which I'm sure is of utmost interest for you, I'll leave the mike to Emmanuel.

Thank you, Jean-Pascal. Good morning, everyone. Let's go now indeed into some detail in our P&L. And let's look at some analysis. Starting with our sales, our sales amounted to €11.4 billion during the first half of 2012. It's an increase by 10.4%. Biggest contributor to the growth was first the scope impact. Jean-Pascal has just been explaining about the interest and the good integration of all the acquisitions that we have made through 2011. They've indeed contributed by a little bit more than €600 million to the growth of our sales in H1. And we can say that integration is well on track, doing well, and that we are pleased with what this new acquisitions are delivering and that therefore this focus that we clearly had during the end of 2011 and the beginning of 2012 on integration is now largely behind us.

Second positive impact, the ForEx impact, plus 4.3%, no surprise. Depreciation of the euro versus most of the main currency and notably the U.S. dollar, the Chinese yuan, I could quote as well the Australian dollar or the British pound. I mean all that has been helping our sales by around €430 million over the first half of the year. Last impact, the organic growth, plus 0.2%, I don't come back on that because, Jean-Pascal, you've been going into some detail on that.

Looking at our margin, our gross profit reached €4.3 billion. It's up plus 9% compared to last year. And when we look at our margin rate, it's 37.7%, it's down 0.7 points. In fact, really the negative driver behind that are, first of all, the scope impact, the acquisition that we have made are coming and are joining the group with a lower level of gross margins. So, this is having a mechanical negative impact.

Second impact, of course the mix impact, which has been negative and negative in several dimensions, negative in the Solutions versus further growth, we've seen the more than 6 points of difference. The evolution of the geographies as well has not been playing positively.

If I look at the launch of new Products, they have been quite numerous in the first half of the year and quite important, and themselves they are having some impact on the gross margin, because at the beginning when we launch a new product, we need some time to get to full targeted cost to produce this new product and until we get there we have some negative impact on our margin. So, these are really the key impacts explaining the negative mix. In addition, as a negative impact, I should also mention of course some inflation on wages and on production cost globally. And all that have been partially but only partially offset by what we have done, notably in terms of positivity, Jean-Pascal has been detailing that.

We've been very well disciplined, I would say, but also very efficient in managing our support function costs over the first half of the year. Of course, it has been cost control, but it has been also a number of implementation of rationalization, neutralization, simplification of the way we operate and all that has been generating a number of savings. These savings made possible to compensate for inflation, they made possible for investments; Jean-Pascal mentioned the growth of spending and investment in terms of R&D. And despite that, we manage organically to decrease the support function cost in the first half of 2012 compared to the first half of 2011.

And the ratio, SFC on net sale, is down from 24.5% for the first half of 2011 to 24.1% in the first half of 2012. All taken into account, we reached an adjusted EBITA of €1.556 billion; it's up 9% compared to the first half of 2011. And the margin rate reaches 13.6%, 0.3 point down compared to the first half of 2011. But if I exclude the impact of the acquisition, we are at the same level. And therefore, we managed to maintain excluding this scope impact the level of margin between last year and this year.

You have here as always a more detailed analysis of the various impacts. I've been really mentioning most of them. Just a few comments on the price impact; we have delivered €141 million for the first half. As Jean-Pascal said, we are expecting some positive elements on the second half but at a lower level that we have achieved through the first half. We believe that we should be for the full year around €200 million of price positive impact.

In terms of productivity, we started the year with an objective ranging between €250 million and €300 million of productivity. And we think that we should be within this range for the full year. One element here on the other line, which is due to a number of non-recurring element in term of increase of some warranty costs and in term of provision on some inventory, which account for this other line of minus €44 million.

Looking now at the evolution of our margin, and we see of course quite diverse evolutions of margin. Best performer IT, very strong growth of the margin, plus 3.8 points reaching 17.5%. Several reasons behind this improvement, first of all, the performance on the H1 2011 had been negatively impacted by a number of elements. So we start with relatively easy comps, but most of the explanation is beyond very strong achievement of IT during this first half in term of price increase, in term of developing the services, in term of management of Solutions and margin solution. All that contributed to this strong increase of the margin on the IT business.

Infrastructure is also positive at plus 0.2 points despite slightly negative organic growth. This is the work that the team is doing on making sure that all the integration of all the business acquired is doing well and priority put on the margin and on profit and improving the profitability on Solutions, and that explains why despite the negative environment, despite a number of negative headwind, they managed to increase by 0.2 their margin

Moving now to Power, minus 1.2 points, while this is a decrease we are still low at a very high level, 20% adjusted EBITDA margin. And really, in the Power division we have felt the pressure of the mix impact. We have felt the pressure of notably the launch of new products. We have seen Solutions growing significantly quicker than Products. We have seen an impact on the geographies as well. That is really explaining why Power is having this decrease in margin against staying at a high level.

Industry, quite a remarkable resilience of the margin, minus 1.1 points despite the significant decrease of the topline on an organic basis. And Industry really managed to increase prices, managed to drive profitability on Solutions, all that to compensate precisely the values that were coming at the level of the topline and of course the negative element that it generates. Last, Buildings, minus 1.6 points, impacted by the negative evolution of the sales and the fact that part of the business has been down as well generating a negative mix.

Going down to the rest of the P&L now; other income and expenses and restructuring, minus €51 million. The amount of restructuring is exactly the same as the one last year at minus €43 million. Then you have other impairment and expenses of minus €8 million, a pretty marginal number; amortization and impairment of intangible, minus €180 million. This is an increase compared to last year which is only driven by the acquisition that we have made in 2011 and which are generating a number of increased amortization. EBIT reached €1.387 billion. It's up as well 9% compared to last year. Net financial expense, pretty stable. We have seen the cost of our debt decreasing by around 30 bps. But as debt was increasing following the acquisition of last year, we have seen an increase of, roughly speaking, €40 million of the interest paid on the debt. This was compensated by a very negative ForEx impact last year, which was not that negative this year.

Income tax, negative €281 million, and income tax rate of minus 23.5%. Here we stay very much stable, I would say, six months after six months. The first half of 2011 was at 24% of tax rate. The whole year of 2011 was at 23%. We're still winning the same kind of magnitude and we believe that it's realistic to be around 24% for the full year. And we have a positive contribution from equity investments, which are – which is largely coming from the joint venture that we have in Russia, Electroshield-Samara. And then, of course, we are doing profit in a number of companies where we are some minority partner and we give back this positive partner that represents minus €45 million. In total, our net income group shares reached €890 million. It's up plus 11%. And if I look at the earnings per share, it reached €1.65 and it's up plus 10%.

Looking at the cash flow now, operating cash flow is at €1.2 billion, slightly impacted by payment that we have made on the restructuring cost that had been provisioned for at the end of 2011. CapEx is growing compared to 2011. We keep investing. The big impact here, of course, is coming from a much improved impact coming from the trade working capital. Last year, remember that we have had this very negative stock Buildings coming from the situation in Japan. This year that did not reproduce. And therefore, we have the traditional pattern where we built some inventory over the first half of the year and that we will deplete this inventory in the second half of the year. And really, here, the impact of €149 million is largely the reflection of this impact on inventory.

Change in non-trade working capital, one element to note here, on a kind of normative basis we have a negative impact on the first half of the year, which is around €150 million, notably because we are paying a number of bonuses to the employees during the first half. This year we have in addition a number of one-off impacts which account for about half of the €300 million here and largely coming from deferred tax payments that are impacting the first half of the year. Altogether free cash flow is reaching €400 million. It would have been even higher without this one-off on the non-trade working capital. We are back to what we generated during the first half of 2010, therefore very much back on a normal pattern.

Dividend is reaching €900 million. Acquisition – reduced amount of acquisition, most of the amount here is coming from the M&C Energy Group acquisition that we have made. And in addition to that we made a small acquisition in wiring devices in China during the first half. Capital increased very small number coming from the stock option and restricted share movement, €22 million. And then on the Other line, minus €225 million; a big part of this element is the ForEx impact on the debt. We have more than 50% of our debt which is dollar or dollar-related. So obviously, when the dollar rises versus euro we have an impact on the debt. The rest of the element, around €70 million, is payment that we have made to the pension plan of the company. In total, the debt reached €6.155 billion, and I'll just come back for a second on the performance of the global free cash flow generation over the last 12 months' period, €2.62 billion. It's a record high for the group.

We keep very strong balance sheet and very strong cash conversion. The cash conversion was described by Jean-Pascal. We have a net-debt-to-adjusted-EBITDA ratio at the end of June 2012 of 1.5 time, very much in line with what we had at the end of 2011. One important element here is to look back at our cash generation, whether in the bad period or in the good period. And you see that over the last five years, the cyclicality of the cash generation has been extremely limited. In fact, we've been quite stable in the cash generation. And why is that? It's because when the time are good, of course we have strong cash generation, but part of that is consumed by working capital growth. But on the contrary, as soon as times are tougher, we are extremely good at managing to reduce the working capital and therefore compensate for a lower growth. And you see that, that gives a very strong cash flow over the last five years.

One word about the return on capital employed. That's remained clearly in the record that we have been giving, 12.2 points for the last 12 months. You have compared to 2011 the impact of the acquisition that we have made in 2011. That will take some time and some quarters to put them in term of contribution to where we expect them to be, and therefore to compensate for the negative impact. And you have also some mechanical impact coming from the depreciation of the euro versus the dollar, which is having a negative impact on the way we calculate this return on capital employed.
Jean-Pascal, I hand over to you for the outlook.

Well, that's going to be brief. Well, first point is that we certainly acknowledge that the world of today is full uncertainty in many parts of the world, but without further deterioration of the economic situation. The end of H1 results make us confirm our guidance at the beginning of the year, which is flat to slightly positive organic sales growth and an adjusted EBITA between 14% and 15%.
So, thank you for your attention for this quick presentation. And now, we are ready to answer your questions.
Right. I think we'll start the questions from the room here. First one, Gaël De Bray.

Thank you very much. Good morning to all of you. So, I've got three questions, actually. The first one relates to the Products versus Solutions mix. The Solutions business grew about 8% in Q1 and was apparently kind of flat in Q2. So, the growth in Solutions seems to be better aligned with that of Products in Q2 now. So, could you comment on how the mix impact on margins has changed between Q1 and Q2 and what should be expected for the second half of the year? Maybe given the backlog you have in the Solutions business, I guess, you have some kind of visibility there.

The second question is on the Buildings business; this division recorded what is probably the weakest margin ever this time in the first half. So, could you elaborate on the various action plans? Maybe you're taking today to turn around the business and also come back on the long-term strategy for that business. Also, I think you said that your focus on M&A integration was now largely behind you. So, does that mean there are now more acquisitions in the pipeline and that you feel more confident about doing acquisitions in the coming months? And maybe last – there would be a fourth question, yeah. Related to the reduction in support function costs, that was quite impressive in the first half; so maybe could you elaborate on the various measures that drove the SG&A cost reduction and maybe the sustainability of these actions going into the second half?
Gaël, I think fortunately you stop because Michel (36:03) is telling me many other people are complaining.

All right, first question Gaël on the Solutions mix, you're right, Q2 was better in terms of mix because the Solutions we're still growing 3% – around 3% higher than Products but reduced. Of course compared to the first quarter where the gap was more significant, it's a better mix. Our sense is that for the rest of the year we should see Solutions continuing to grow significantly quicker than Product. Now, I'm not able of course to be more specific, but we would certainly expect this Solutions drive to continue versus the Products.

I would – just to answer terms better, or it's not better, it's – these are two business methods, right, higher margin, higher CapEx on Products and lower margin, better asset term on Solutions. And this is what we work upon in parallel, but it's clear that – I confirm that we have a selling background in Solutions but the priority, as we said, is to master the Solutions model which we are doing, therefore decelerating the growth rate from differential between Products and Solutions. By the way, the mix swings are also affecting this proportion because some of the countries tend to be more Solutions driven and some of the countries tend to be more Products driven. So, it's also affected by the kind of business we have from one geography to the other one.

Now, switching on to Buildings, yeah, well, Buildings, as you know, has two character – first you have to put Buildings at Schneider in perspective. It's 40% of our business because in Buildings we sell all the active part, which is Power with energy monitoring, very often for partners. So therefore, there is a part of the business which is clearly in our Power business which is having very, very solid dynamics in the first half.

What we call Buildings in the reporting of our result is the building console part of our business. And there, you have two characteristics. We are more major-country exposed and at the same time, we are driving investment to deploy this business in other geographies. So to answer your question, some of the major countries, they are not at the best of the economic performance. So therefore, the margin on the planning was under pressure and at the same time, we are investing in integration teams, in specialized teams in new geographies and that weighs on the margin. But if you look at the total margin we do with our customers in the Buildings area, we are one of the largest players in the building environment – in the active part of the building environment in the world.

Acquisition, that's a very good question; I wanted to go back on that. We've been not doing major acquisitions in the past 12 months because we had been active one year ago and we wanted to make sure that the acquisition we had made would be well integrated in our company and that all the plans of synergies will be put into place. While this has been done and it has been done very properly, we feel very satisfied about the level of integration of last year's acquisition plus the level of cash generation has been very satisfactory also, and the action plans are well in place to make it sustainable. So, we shall now be more active on the front of acquisition but in a soft manner and with a clear preference for the model of mid to small-sized acquisitions. But we are – yes, we're going to be back to acquisitions from now on. Prediction of SFC?

On SFC, as always you have two types of measures. You have the very short-term cost control measures which are delaying or suppressing a number of contracts which are necessary sustainable, and then you have the long-term measure that we described in terms of working better and more efficiently. You'll remember that we have an objective over three years to reduce the SFC on the sales ratio. On the first half, we are going to – we have achieved 0.4% and nothing that we're going to do has caused the global objective in one year.

So for the second part of the year, I think that we are going to continue to work on the long-term measure and that should continue to contribute. I am not saying that we would necessarily be as restrictive in the cost evolution. And notably, there are a number of areas we want to continue to invest in terms of R&D, but in terms of new area of growth, new economies, and that could have some impact on the second half.
Alfred (41:00)?

Yes. Could you comment on your business evolution and outlook in China, more precisely what you see by end markets currently, what is stabilizing really, what is possibly rebounding? And then, I was just wondering on raw material costs, you had a pretty good evolution in your EBITA numbers in the first half. What is currently the outlook for you for the second half, please?
On what, sorry?
Raw materials.

Okay. Quick word about China; the – what we found is that China has stabilized. So, it's in the negatives but single-digit negatives at the level of what we had in Q1. And clearly, we are also comparing to very high figures in 2011. I mean that people have to realize – we all have to realize that there was an injection of a stimulus package three years ago in China that was constructed in 2010 and electrified in 2011. So, I believe that for the people with whom we have had a continuous dialogue in the past two years, we always consider that there would be a kind of boom. And then you have oscillations after to come back to a normal trajectory of growth.

What are we doing in China today? We are moving very actively to the west and putting into place the right lineups of products, the right offers, to address the specific needs of the developing regions of China. I'm not personally concerned about the mid-term perspective of China. We've got striking differences of dynamics between regions. What we see today is that there is probably a renewed investment into the infrastructure under the impulse of the government, which has not yet translated into ourselves. There is also a conversion of the economy from an export-driven model to a consumption-driven model, which means that, for instance, Industry is low at the moment because export – machine manufacturers are exporting less at the moment, but we see more dynamics into, for instance, residential power sales, especially in the new regions.

So at the moment, stabilization, no sign of clear rebound at this stage. I don't expect big rebound before the end of the year or beginning of next year. But we see good dynamics in parts of the economy, the difference of dynamics being more driven by geography than by end segments at this stage. And Industry has been low at – during the past – during the first half in China because we work a lot with machine manufacturers. We're exporting and we're suffering from the crisis, particularly in Europe.

Now, one thing that is – that I want to underline is that China is obviously very important for Schneider but we also lots of – we've spent a lot of our energy in the past three years to diversify the rest of our presence in other new economies and particularly, we've tripled our size in India in two years. We've significantly increased our size in Brazil, doubled our size. We've increased a lot in Russia and in many other places. So, it's a very diverse presence in new economies that we have. We generate a 5% differential with major countries including the negative of China.

On raw materials, your second question, Alfred (44:52), It's almost neutral in the first half, very slightly negative. We do expect the second half to be more positive, and therefore the impact excluding the ForEx impact being overall positive for the full year.
Do we have another question? Okay. We'll take questions from the call.
We have a question from Mr. Mark Troman from Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Sir, please go ahead.
